dublinCore.dc:title: 113 HR 3559 IH: Entrepreneur-in-Residence Act of 2013
dublinCore.dc:rights: Pursuant to Title 17 Section 105 of the United States Code, this file is not subject to copyright protection and is in the public domain.

action.action-desc: Mr. Honda (for himself and Mr. Lankford) introduced the following bill; which was referred to the Committee on Oversight and Government Reform

form.official-title: To establish a program to accelerate entrepreneurship and innovation by partnering world-class entrepreneurs with Federal agencies.

section.text: This Act may be cited as the Entrepreneur-in-Residence Act of 2013 .

paragraph.text: the term Director means the Director of the Office of Personnel Management;
the term program means the Federal entrepreneur-in-residence program established under section 3(a);
the term entrepreneur-in-residence means an individual appointed to a position under the program; and
the term agency means an Executive agency, as defined in section 105 of title 5, United States Code.

subsection.text: The Director, in consultation with the Administrator of the Small Business Administration and the Secretary of Commerce, shall establish a Federal entrepreneur-in-residence program under which the Director, with the concurrence of the head of an agency, may appoint an entrepreneur-in-residence to a position in the excepted service in the agency to carry out the duties described in subsection (d).
The mission of the program shall be to—

paragraph.text: provide for better outreach by the Federal Government to the private sector;
strengthen coordination and interaction between the Federal Government and the private sector on issues relevant to entrepreneurs and business concerns; and
make Federal programs simpler, quicker, more efficient, and more responsive to the needs of business concerns and entrepreneurs.

subparagraph.text: shall appoint entrepreneurs-in-residence under the program during each year; and
may not appoint more than 10 entrepreneurs-in-residence during any year.

paragraph.text: The Director shall select entrepreneurs-in-residence from among individuals who—

subparagraph.text: have demonstrated success in working with business concerns and entrepreneurs; or
have successfully developed, invented, or created a product and brought the product to the marketplace.

paragraph.text: In appointing entrepreneurs-in-residence, the Director shall—

subparagraph.text: give priority to placing entrepreneurs-in-residence across the Federal Government at separate agencies; and
to the extent practicable, not appoint more than 2 entrepreneurs-in-residence to positions in the same agency during the same year.
shall be a full-time employee of the agency to which the entrepreneur-in-residence is appointed; and
may not serve as an entrepreneur-in-residence for more than a period of 2 years.

paragraph.text: assist Federal agencies in improving outreach to business concerns and entrepreneurs;
provide recommendations to the head of the agency employing the entrepreneur-in-residence on inefficient or duplicative programs, if any, at the agency;

provide recommendations to the head of the agency employing the entrepreneur-in-residence on methods to improve program efficiency at the agency or new initiatives, if any, that may be instituted at the agency;
facilitate meetings and forums to educate business concerns and entrepreneurs on programs or initiatives of the agency employing the entrepreneur-in-residence;
facilitate in-service sessions with employees of the agency employing the entrepreneur-in-residence on issues of concern to business concerns and entrepreneurs; and
provide technical assistance or mentorship to business concerns and entrepreneurs in accessing programs at the agency employing the entrepreneur-in-residence.

subsection.text: An entrepreneur-in-residence shall be compensated at the rate of $1 a year.
An entrepreneur-in-residence shall report directly to the head of the agency employing the entrepreneur-in-residence.

The Director may establish an informal working group of entrepreneurs-in-residence to allow for entrepreneurs-in-residence to meet to discuss best practices, experiences, and recommendations in order to create an informal knowledge base for current and future entrepreneurs-in-residence.
The Director may not appoint an entrepreneur-in-residence under this section after September 30, 2017.
